sources.data_found: OpenMind system: Totally there are around 70 compute nodes, 3500 CPU cores, 48 TB of RAM, and 340 GPUs, including 142 A100-80GB GPUs.

Many multi-cpu servers have GPUs – the Engaging cluster has 366 online. Across all ORCD systems (Engaging, Satori, Openmind and Supercloud) there are more than 1400 GPUs, of various generations. Of these, only 32 are currently the latest generation H100 GPUs, although another 96 are in the process of being added to Engaging.
The cluster consists of six nodes with four nvidia gpus each. Three nodes have four v100s cards and three nodes have four rtx6000 cards.

TX-GAIA system comprises nearly 900 Intel processors and 900 Nvidia GPU accelerators. The new system named TX-GAIA for Green AI Accelerator was ranked by TOP500 as the most powerful AI supercomputer at any university in the world, powered by 896 NVIDIA Tensor Core V100 GPUs.
Computing majors are the largest at MIT.

student_data.notes: Data is from January 2020 as stated on the EECS department website. Undergrad count is the total EECS undergraduate enrollment. MEng students (270) are listed as grad_cs_count. PhD count (700) is from the EECS admission process page. These are the most recent specific enrollment numbers found from official sources. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: PSFC cluster: 3 nodes with 4 RTX6000 cards each = 12 GPUs
Calculated from total of 1400+ GPUs across all systems minus specified models

gpu_resources.notes:
CLUSTERS INCLUDED + CALCULATIONS

1) OpenMind (ORCD/BCS/McGovern): 142 A100-80GB GPUs (confirmed from both ORCD docs and OpenMind website). Total of ~330-340 GPUs in cluster.

2) Engaging cluster (ORCD): 366 GPUs total, with 32 H100 GPUs currently and 96 more H100s being added (total 128 H100s).

3) SuperCloud (MIT Lincoln Lab): 850+ NVIDIA Volta (V100) GPUs from ORCD docs.

4) PSFC GPU cluster: 6 nodes total - 3 nodes × 4 V100 = 12 V100s, 3 nodes × 4 RTX6000 = 12 RTX6000s.

5) TX-GAIA (MIT Lincoln Lab Supercomputing Center): 896 V100 GPUs.

TOTAL CALCULATIONS:
- H100 SXM: 32 (current) + 96 (being added) = 128
- A100 80GB: 142 (confirmed from OpenMind)
- V100: 850 (SuperCloud) + 12 (PSFC) + 896 (TX-GAIA) - 850 (possible overlap) = 908
- RTX 6000: 12 (PSFC cluster)
- Other GPUs: ~212 (from total 1400+ minus specified models)

Note: April 2024 newsletter states 'more than 1400 GPUs' total across all ORCD systems.

analysis_notes: Data collected shows MIT has substantial GPU resources distributed across multiple clusters (ORCD systems, TX-GAIA supercomputer). Student enrollment data is from 2020 - the most recent specific numbers available from official sources. Computing majors are noted as 'the largest at MIT' but exact 2024 numbers were not accessible in the search results.
